VOL. XXX, No. 39
JAY GETS CONTRIBUTIONS
FROM FAMOUS WRITERS
AND CARTOONISTS
John Held, Jr. Draws Cover; Farr,
Tad, Reilly, Gettier, Cobb and
Others Contribute

John Held, Jr. has drawn the
cover for the Celebrity Number of
h e Black and Blue Jay, the staff
announced yesterday. The drawing by the famous artist, which is
already in the hands of the engraver, is to be the subject of four
color plates. This is the first time
that the Jay has had a cover which
was sent through -the presses four
times. John Held, Jr. is probably the most well-known cover
artist in the United States. He
does a large percentage of the
covers for both Judge-and Life and
his work is nationally known.
Eight Prominent Men
it was announced at the same

time that eight other prominent
men.have come through with contributions and that four more
.letters have been received. Material is coming in faster every day
as the time of publication-nears.
The "best of. all issues," is slated
to appear on the night of the twenty-sixth, the evening of the first
Barnstormer production.
Among the contributions received is one from W.G. Farr, well
known . artist, whose work often
appears in Judge. He proved him‘self.interested in the Blue Jay, by
signing himself, -yours. for a million circulation.'' -When he was
asked for a short history of his
life, as all -the other contributors
were, he sent a finger print. Another who has recently sent in a
dialogue is H. W. Hanneman one
of Life's staff. His writing is entitled "Thin Days in the Underworld."
Gettier
A two page drawing by Paul
Reilly, artist to Life and Judge,
showing a combination of the bedroom farce and the historical
drama, has been received and
should add spice to the publication. Still more interesting is the
two page drawing by Clarence Gettier, -prominent Baltimore newspaper artist. His drawing tells
of -Spring Coming to College."
Indeed, if we are to believe Mr.
Gettier, a young man's fancy is
very fancy in the spring.
McReady Huston, of fame for
work in Life, College Comics, The
Red Book, and more particularly
The Saturday Evening Post, has
written "Please Pass The Ether,"
a short sketch which, the staff
says, is very funny. Mr. Huston's
Work appears regularly in "Short
Turns and Encores," in The Post.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 16, 1926.
BLUE JAYS TO PLAY
AT PENN IVY BALL

Another important engagement for the Blue Jay
Orchestra will be its appearance at the University of
Pennsylvania during t 11 e
week-end of April 17 and 18.
At the Philadelphia college
they will play at the Ivy Ball
celebration which is one of
the most elaborate spring
festivals staged by any university in the country. The
Jays will play twice during
their stay at Penn.
As announced several
weeks ago, the orchestra will
also - play during Easter
Week at Roseland Hall on
Broadway. The Jay syncopaters are working steadily
in preparation for this engagement.

Meredith Disabled

By Injury To Leg
Frank Meredith, star quarter
miler of the track team, will
probably be unable to min again
this year.
Meredith severely injured his
leg while running for a street
car. Though the extent of his injury is not known, his services
will probably be lost for the remainder of the season.

false believer in reincarnation, influences His Majesty to believe

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 16, 1926.

"THE OLD ORDER CHANGETH" VERY LITTLE
Of late years, the NEWS-LETTER has made a very commend'able effort to avoid triteness as much as possible. Consequently the unexpected has collie to be more or less expected, especially in the editorial column. However, we take the liberty of
deserting this estimable policy temporarily, and expressing
some of the venerable "old order changeth" ideas.
First, a word in regard to the recently departed seniors of
the staff. They did their work well, and succeeded in leaving
the paper better than they found it. They were conscientous
executives and pleasant working mates; if higher praise can be
bestowed on college journalists, it is yet to be discovered. We
take the paper from their hands with the sense of having a
good foundation to work on, and a high standard to uphold.
So far, so good. The rub comes in the ways and means of
upholding these standards, or, to state the question more baldly, the policy of .the NEW'S-LETTER. There seem to be two distinct opinions on the matter. Many think that the NEWSLETTER should hark back to its custom of a few years ago and
act as an impartial recorder of campus opinion. On the other
hand about an equal number hold the opposite view, which has
prevailed recently, that the editorial should be an expression
of personal opinion.
Laying ourselves open to charges of moral cowardice, if not
4-6f---ab-S-Olute-moral turpitude, we decline to- adopt either of the
clear cut positions, but prefer rather to struggle along the
"misty flats" of the middle course..
We feel that it is practically impossible to carry out the first
idea—that of recording campus opinion. In the first place it
is very difficult to find out what campus opinion really is. Ten
men, fired by some great idea, and with any proclivities for
talking, may make quite a stir on the campus, although they
are opposed by several times as many of their more phlegmate
fellows. So short of sending out a questionnaire, what the
campus thinks, when it thinks at all, is something of a riddle.
As for the second theory, the constant appearance in print
of the editor's personal opinions and whims, will, unless he is
very exceptional, soon become a bore, and will carry very little
weight.
In view of these considerations, the NEWS-LETTER shall adhere to the above mentioned middle course. We shall appear
neither as an unpersonal oracle, nor shall we give vent to irresponsible musings. But selecting as issues subjects upon
which campus opinion is divided, we shall then venture our own
opinion.
To come down to earth, all that this rather pompous declarato show is that the NEWS-LETTER policy has changed
tivn
vorv little.

Along with the other fast-fading Seniors, Yes and No is on
the verge of a mental, physical and moral breakdown. Consequently, the editors of the NEWS-LETTER are looking about
them for another ambiguity of the type that enjoys scribbling
a few well chosen words at the head of another's contribution.
If there be such at large, let him proceed to make a noise, and
lo! the one and only and original Yes and No shall hark,—if
not heed. If none such there be who is, at least, a genius, it is
written, aye and sworn, that this column will temain in the
bosom of that great, big family which is the NEWS-LETTER editorial staff. In the face of such a calamity, brethren, we call
upon you to rise up in your wrath and smite your typewriters.
The first of the smitings follows:
"We lament—and with all our lamenting are amused.
And could there be any more amusing or gratifying pastime than to 'sit in' at any one of numerous, gatherings
held about the campus under the dubious title of class
and board meetings, particularly during a time when 'elections' are in order. We like to sit in a secluded corner
and watch the inner and outer workings of the political
machinery of our glorious fellows in learning. There is
:oinething refreshing in 'absolute puerility. It gives us
such a satisfying sense of our own perspicacity.
-We contend that it is amusing since in our old-fashionedness 'election' connotates the passing of divine right
to the rule of. the ruled. But not so at Hopkins; in the
scholarly atmosphere of our mossy traditions we pass year
in and year out allowing the 'personality pluses' to appoint
themsetves. They are elected in form; appointed in spirit.
Unfortunately, it seems to us, the great gods, personality,
fraternity rating and athletic record are not sure guides
to determine eligibility for office, and that in choosing
such officers personal adaptability is left utterly out of
account. For witness any so-called election on the campus. Nominations are always in abundance. We feel
grateful when some one stops them before a roll call is
taken. But we wait in vain for the nominators to substantiate their choice by verbal platform.
"Further we hazard that there is confusion in the mind
of the undergraduate as to the meaning of the word 'discussion,' for at the invitation to participate in this discussion of candidates there is shuffling, hesitancy and then - - sweet, beautiful silence. As it stands there is a show of
hands, a mumble of 'ayes,' perhaps, and a 'great big campus leader' is elected. But to repeat, that word 'discussion,' it seems to produce a sort of Stage fright pr panacea
to the end that thought, constructive or destructive, ceases
immediately in favor of a vague wandering hope that by it
spin and roll chance the right man will be elected any way.
"Our amusement resolves itself into wondering what
mental inhibitory process functions whereby ideas are assassinated rather than associated. Preceding election
never a murmer—twenty minutes after the Barn and sundu fraternity houses are a-buzz with most 'pointed, and,
curiously enough,sound evidence supporting the belief that
a poor choice has been made.
"We timidly suggest that the discussion take place before the election; not after it.
"Will it?
F. M. H.
"We doubt it."

Dorm Committee
Announces Dance
The social committee of the
Alumni Memorial -Dormitory has
announced that a pre-Easter dance.
will be held in the Commons Room
on Friday evenirig, March 19. The
music will be furnished by the
Blue Jay Orchestra.
This dance is for residents only.
However, there may be extra tickets in which case V residents may
invite their friends. • There is consIderable interest among the residents in regards to this dance and
a large number of tickets have
already been sold.
Tickets can be obtained from J.
Balls, chairman of the social committee or from the entry representatives. The subscription is two
dollars per couple.

think," said Dr. Reeves, "that war

VOL. XXX, No. 39
JAY GETS CONTRIBUTIONS
FROM FAMOUS WRITERS
AND CARTOONISTS
John Held, Jr. Draws Cover; Farr,
Tad, Reilly, Gettier, Cobb and
Others Contribute

John Held, Jr. has drawn the
cover for the Celebrity Number of
h e Black and Blue Jay, the staff
announced yesterday. The drawing by the famous artist, which is
already in the hands of the engraver, is to be the subject of four
color plates. This is the first time
that the Jay has had a cover which
was sent through -the presses four
times. John Held, Jr. is probably the most well-known cover
artist in the United States. He
does a large percentage of the
covers for both Judge-and Life and
his work is nationally known.
Eight Prominent Men
it was announced at the same

time that eight other prominent
men.have come through with contributions and that four more
.letters have been received. Material is coming in faster every day
as the time of publication-nears.
The "best of. all issues," is slated
to appear on the night of the twenty-sixth, the evening of the first
Barnstormer production.
Among the contributions received is one from W.G. Farr, well
known . artist, whose work often
appears in Judge. He proved him‘self.interested in the Blue Jay, by
signing himself, -yours. for a million circulation.'' -When he was
asked for a short history of his
life, as all -the other contributors
were, he sent a finger print. Another who has recently sent in a
dialogue is H. W. Hanneman one
of Life's staff. His writing is entitled "Thin Days in the Underworld."
Gettier
A two page drawing by Paul
Reilly, artist to Life and Judge,
showing a combination of the bedroom farce and the historical
drama, has been received and
should add spice to the publication. Still more interesting is the
two page drawing by Clarence Gettier, -prominent Baltimore newspaper artist. His drawing tells
of -Spring Coming to College."
Indeed, if we are to believe Mr.
Gettier, a young man's fancy is
very fancy in the spring.
McReady Huston, of fame for
work in Life, College Comics, The
Red Book, and more particularly
The Saturday Evening Post, has
written "Please Pass The Ether,"
a short sketch which, the staff
says, is very funny. Mr. Huston's
Work appears regularly in "Short
Turns and Encores," in The Post.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 16, 1926.
BLUE JAYS TO PLAY
AT PENN IVY BALL

Another important engagement for the Blue Jay
Orchestra will be its appearance at the University of
Pennsylvania during t 11 e
week-end of April 17 and 18.
At the Philadelphia college
they will play at the Ivy Ball
celebration which is one of
the most elaborate spring
festivals staged by any university in the country. The
Jays will play twice during
their stay at Penn.
As announced several
weeks ago, the orchestra will
also - play during Easter
Week at Roseland Hall on
Broadway. The Jay syncopaters are working steadily
in preparation for this engagement.

Frank Meredith, star quarter

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 16, 1926.

"THE OLD ORDER CHANGETH" VERY LITTLE
Of late years, the NEWS-LETTER has made a very commend'able effort to avoid triteness as much as possible. Consequently the unexpected has collie to be more or less expected, especially in the editorial column. However, we take the liberty of
deserting this estimable policy temporarily, and expressing
some of the venerable "old order changeth" ideas.
First, a word in regard to the recently departed seniors of
the staff. They did their work well, and succeeded in leaving
the paper better than they found it. They were conscientous
executives and pleasant working mates; if higher praise can be
bestowed on college journalists, it is yet to be discovered. We
take the paper from their hands with the sense of having a
good foundation to work on, and a high standard to uphold.
So far, so good. The rub comes in the ways and means of
upholding these standards, or, to state the question more baldly, the policy of .the NEW'S-LETTER. There seem to be two distinct opinions on the matter. Many think that the NEWSLETTER should hark back to its custom of a few years ago and
act as an impartial recorder of campus opinion. On the other
hand about an equal number hold the opposite view, which has
prevailed recently, that the editorial should be an expression
of personal opinion.
Laying ourselves open to charges of moral cowardice, if not
4-6f---ab-S-Olute-moral turpitude, we decline to- adopt either of the
clear cut positions, but prefer rather to struggle along the
"misty flats" of the middle course..
We feel that it is practically impossible to carry out the first
idea—that of recording campus opinion. In the first place it
is very difficult to find out what campus opinion really is. Ten
men, fired by some great idea, and with any proclivities for
talking, may make quite a stir on the campus, although they
are opposed by several times as many of their more phlegmate
fellows. So short of sending out a questionnaire, what the
campus thinks, when it thinks at all, is something of a riddle.
As for the second theory, the constant appearance in print
of the editor's personal opinions and whims, will, unless he is
very exceptional, soon become a bore, and will carry very little
weight.
In view of these considerations, the NEWS-LETTER shall adhere to the above mentioned middle course. We shall appear
neither as an unpersonal oracle, nor shall we give vent to irresponsible musings. But selecting as issues subjects upon
which campus opinion is divided, we shall then venture our own
opinion.
To come down to earth, all that this rather pompous declarato show is that the NEWS-LETTER policy has changed
tivn
vorv little.

Along with the other fast-fading Seniors, Yes and No is on
the verge of a mental, physical and moral breakdown. Consequently, the editors of the NEWS-LETTER are looking about
them for another ambiguity of the type that enjoys scribbling
a few well chosen words at the head of another's contribution.
If there be such at large, let him proceed to make a noise, and
lo! the one and only and original Yes and No shall hark,—if
not heed. If none such there be who is, at least, a genius, it is
written, aye and sworn, that this column will temain in the
bosom of that great, big family which is the NEWS-LETTER editorial staff. In the face of such a calamity, brethren, we call
upon you to rise up in your wrath and smite your typewriters.
The first of the smitings follows:
"We lament—and with all our lamenting are amused.
And could there be any more amusing or gratifying pastime than to 'sit in' at any one of numerous, gatherings
held about the campus under the dubious title of class
and board meetings, particularly during a time when 'elections' are in order. We like to sit in a secluded corner
and watch the inner and outer workings of the political
machinery of our glorious fellows in learning. There is
:oinething refreshing in 'absolute puerility. It gives us
such a satisfying sense of our own perspicacity.
-We contend that it is amusing since in our old-fashionedness 'election' connotates the passing of divine right
to the rule of. the ruled. But not so at Hopkins; in the
scholarly atmosphere of our mossy traditions we pass year
in and year out allowing the 'personality pluses' to appoint
themsetves. They are elected in form; appointed in spirit.
Unfortunately, it seems to us, the great gods, personality,
fraternity rating and athletic record are not sure guides
to determine eligibility for office, and that in choosing
such officers personal adaptability is left utterly out of
account. For witness any so-called election on the campus. Nominations are always in abundance. We feel
grateful when some one stops them before a roll call is
taken. But we wait in vain for the nominators to substantiate their choice by verbal platform.
"Further we hazard that there is confusion in the mind
of the undergraduate as to the meaning of the word 'discussion,' for at the invitation to participate in this discussion of candidates there is shuffling, hesitancy and then - - sweet, beautiful silence. As it stands there is a show of
hands, a mumble of 'ayes,' perhaps, and a 'great big campus leader' is elected. But to repeat, that word 'discussion,' it seems to produce a sort of Stage fright pr panacea
to the end that thought, constructive or destructive, ceases
immediately in favor of a vague wandering hope that by it
spin and roll chance the right man will be elected any way.
"Our amusement resolves itself into wondering what
mental inhibitory process functions whereby ideas are assassinated rather than associated. Preceding election
never a murmer—twenty minutes after the Barn and sundu fraternity houses are a-buzz with most 'pointed, and,
curiously enough,sound evidence supporting the belief that
a poor choice has been made.
"We timidly suggest that the discussion take place before the election; not after it.
"Will it?
F. M. H.
"We doubt it."

which does not conform to the
requirements of the council is automatically in a state of war with
